The objective of this exercise is to learn how to use a .gitignore file in Git to ignore unwanted files and folders, such as .log files and a log folder, so that they are not tracked or committed to the repository.
3. Existing Git repository linked to a remote repository (GitHub).
Step 2 — Create .log File and log Folder
echo "This is a log file" > test.log
This step creates a sample log file and a folder named log containing another sample file.
This creates a .gitignore file with patterns to ignore all .log files and the entire log folder.
The git add command stages the .gitignore file for commit. git status confirms that the file is staged and will be included in the next commit.
git commit -m "Added .gitignore to ignore .log files and log folder"
The git commit command records the change in the local repository, and git push sends the change to the remote repository on GitHub.
By using the .gitignore file, we successfully configured Git to ignore specific unwanted files (.log) and folders (log/). This ensures these files are not tracked or pushed to the remote repository.

Git Hands-On Lab — Merge & Conflict Resolution (Execution Report)
Demonstrate branching, making branch-specific changes, creating conflicting changes on master, and preparing for a merge + conflict resolution.
• GitDemo repository initialized and connected to remote.
Step 1 — Navigate to repository & check state
Description: Ensured we are inside the GitDemo repository and the working tree was clean on the starting branch.
Step 2 — Configure diff/merge tool and create branch
Description: Set up P4Merge (optional) and created a new branch GitWork.
Step 3 — Create hello.xml on GitWork and commit
Hello from branch GitWork – line A
Description: Created a branch-specific file and committed it on the GitWork branch.
Step 4 — Update hello.xml on GitWork and commit
echo "Branch update: This is branch-specific content." >> hello.xml
Description: Added an extra line to hello.xml and committed the change on GitWork.
Step 5 — Add conflicting hello.xml on master and commit
git commit -m "Add conflicting hello.xml on master"
Description: Created a different version of hello.xml on main to create a deliberate conflict for the future merge.
Step 6 — Inspect history and prepare for merge
Description: The commit graph shows diverging commits (separate commits on GitWork and main). This confirms that a merge will produce a conflict in hello.xml.
To perform the merge and resolve conflicts, follow these steps:
If conflicts occur, Git will list the files with conflicts (e.g., hello.xml).
3. Launch the configured merge tool to resolve conflicts:
Resolve conflicts in the 3-way view (LOCAL, BASE, REMOTE). Save the resolved file(s) and exit the merge tool.
git commit -m "Resolved merge conflict for hello.xml"
5. Push the resolved main branch to the remote:
6. Optionally, add temporary backup files to .gitignore, commit and push the .gitignore if needed.

Note: I did not find screenshots of the actual merge/mergetool UI in the images you provided. If you run the merge and capture screenshots of the conflict markers and the merge tool, I will insert them into the document.
Description: After resolving conflicts and committing, delete the branch if it is no longer needed and inspect the history.

The repository now contains branch-specific changes and a conflicting file on main. Follow the merge steps above to resolve conflicts. Share screenshots of the merge/mergetool run if you want them embedded.
Git Merge & Conflict Resolution - Step by Step Execution
Step 1: Navigate to the Git Repository
Open Git Bash and navigate to the GitDemo repository.
Check the current status to ensure you are on the correct branch (GitWork).
Stage any changes and commit them before merging to ensure a clean working directory.
Switch from GitWork branch to main branch to prepare for merging.
Pull the latest changes from the remote main branch to ensure it is up to date.
Merge the changes from GitWork branch into the main branch.
Verify that merge is successful and no conflicts remain.
